componenttext: Good day, and welcome to The Dow Chemical Company's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Howard Ungerleider, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. Good morning, everyone, and welcome. As usual, we're making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This call is the property of The Dow Chemical Company. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. Good morning, everyone, and welcome. As usual, we're making this call available to investors and the media via webcast. This call is the property of The Dow Chemical Company. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without Dow's expressed written consent is strictly prohibited.
On the call with me today are Andrew Liveris, Dow's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Bill Weideman, Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Jerome Peribere, President and Chief Executive Officer of Dow Advanced Materials; and David Johnson, Director in Investor Relations.
Around 6:30 this morning, April 28, our earnings release went out on Business Wire and was posted on the Internet at Dow's website, dow.com. We have prepared some slides to supplement our comments in this conference call. The slides are posted on our website on the Presentations page of the Investor Relations section or through the link to our webcast.  
As you know, some of our comments today may include statements about our expectations for the future. Those expectations involve risks and uncertainties. We cannot guarantee the accuracy of any forecasts or estimates. And we don't plan to update any forward-looking statements during the quarter. If you'd like more information on the risks involved in forward-looking statements, please see our SEC filings. 
In addition, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure and other associated disclosures are contained in our earnings release or on our website. Our earnings release, as well as recent SEC filings, are available on the Internet at dow.com.
The agenda for today's call is on Slide 3. Now I'd like to hand the call over to Andrew.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss our first quarter results. Now to get you to turn to Slide 4. If I could sum up the quarter in just a few words, it would be this: We are a company that continues to delive
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss our first quarter results. Now to get you to turn to Slide 4. If I could sum up the quarter in just a few words, it would be this: We are a company that continues to deliver on its commitments, and we believe our performance in the first quarter represents a pivotal point in demonstrating the earnings power of the new Dow. 
The benefits of staying true to our strategic agenda are clear. And we are proving it quarter after quarter. Our results, once again, show the merits of our strategy in several key ways, starting with our broad-based top line growth and significant EBITDA margin expansion.
Let me summarize a few high-level takeaways from the quarter. Operating earnings were $0.43 per share, up significantly from $0.11 per share in the first quarter of last year. Sales were up a robust 33% year-over-year on a pro forma basis, and excluding divestitures, driven by significant improvements in both price and volume. And on a sequential basis, our growth continued as well, with sales up 8% over the fourth quarter pointing to a strengthening global recovery.
Another very encouraging sign was our volume growth in both North America and Europe. Each up an impressive 11% compared with last year. Emerging geographies grew as well, with volume up 27% on a year-over-year basis. In fact, volume in China was up an impressive 46%. All of this pushed our global operating rate to levels not seen since the second quarter of 2008. And our manufacturing momentum improved as the quarter progressed despite several unplanned outages.
EBITDA increased $877 million versus the same quarter last year, and was up more than 60% in the combined Performance segments. EBITDA margin expanded both year-over-year and sequentially at the enterprise level. And finally, our joint ventures continue to outperform with equity earnings up more than $200 million year-over-year, reaching a record $304 million driven by performance at Dow Corning, EQUATE and MEGlobal.
Let me turn to Slide 5. We stayed true to our strategic path and, in fact, made great progress on our key milestones. Financially, we are delivering on the earnings power of the new portfolio, especially in our Performance businesses and in emerging geographies. Operationally, we delivered cost reductions of $275 million in the first quarter. We remain well ahead of plan and are currently on annual run rate of $1.8 billion, which is ahead of our commitments. Strategically, we exceeded our growth synergy targets by delivering $530 million in revenue on a run-rate basis, while at the same time, we maintained our commitment to growth increasing our investment in research and development by 10%. We also made substantial progress in achieving our goal to divest $2 billion of non-strategic assets in 2010 and remain on track to deliver $5.5 billion in divestments in just 12 months, more than our commitment of $5 billion and in half the time.
On Slide 6, as most of you know, we signed a definitive agreement to sell the Styron division for just over $1.6 billion. Additionally, this deal can include supply and service contracts that will generate substantial value for Dow in the neighborhood of $400 million. This brings the total value of the deal to more than $2 billion, the high-end of our stated target for 2010. The value reflects what we consider an excellent multiple of over 8x EBITDA. The sale of Styron will be our fifth non-core divestment since April 2009, all at favorable multiples.
On Slide 7. Another feature of our earnings call has been to exhibit the tracking tool that provides a look into industry- and market-demand trends across our geographic footprint. This look underscores the unique view we have into the emerging global economic recovery, based on our participation in the value chains of a vast array of industries and end markets. And the picture is bright.
On Slide 8. Starting with an operating segment view, volume was up across virtually all of our businesses. And we are seeing increased demand in a wide variety of end markets, most of which are tied to consumer spending. Electronics, appliances and other durable goods and furniture, as well as consumer staples all showed strong growth. In addition, the automotive sector in North America is improving. And in Asia, it's accelerating.
And finally, there's increased demand in our Water business, which drove improved results, especially in Materials. These trends are particularly relevant given the alignment with the global megatrends that will drive our long-term performance and demonstrate that our new portfolio is very well-positioned. And you can see on the right of the slide, infrastructure stimulus spending still hasn't found its way through many value chains and commercial construction in developed regions continues to lag.  But some good news is that the Housing segment seems to have finally come off of its historic lows.
On Slide 9. Turning now to a geographic look. We see a similar story with a few lingering challenges. We have our eye on high unemployment in developed regions, so we are seeing positive signs that job markets have stabilized. The potential for asset and credit bubbles in emerging geographies and lingering concerns surrounding sovereign debt in Southern Europe could both be potential drags in global growth. However, these factors are clearly outweighed by the strengths that we are seeing. 
The overall global economic environment is on a stronger footing with the highlight being significant demand growth in Europe and North America. In addition, the step change and the relative cost position of U.S. Gulf Coast natural gas provides even further strength for Dow.  Finally, continuing rapid growth in emerging geographies led by China, where demand, as I said, was up an impressive 46%, was driven partly by growing domestic consumption. 
In summary, Dow's vast portfolio and broad geographic reach provide us with a unique perspective on the trends that are shaping the global economic recovery.
I would now like to turn the call over to Bill, who will give you some more detail on how these trends drove our results in the quarter.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Let's begin with a detailed review of our first quarter results on Slide 10.  Reported sales were up $13.4 billion, an increase of 48% over the same period last year, and 8% higher than the fourth quarter of 2009. On a pro forma basis a
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Let's begin with a detailed review of our first quarter results on Slide 10.  Reported sales were up $13.4 billion, an increase of 48% over the same period last year, and 8% higher than the fourth quarter of 2009. On a pro forma basis and excluding divestitures, year-over-year sales were up 33% driven by volume growth of 16% and increased of price of 17%. 
EBITDA excluding certain items was up on a year-over-year basis by $877 million to $1.8 billion. On a sequential basis, EBITDA was up $356 million, an impressive increase considering that we had some margin compression in our Performance businesses due to rapid run-up in propylene costs. 
Earnings, excluding certain items, were $0.43 per share. The current quarter included $0.02 per share unfavorable impact for certain items. Details for these items are included in the appendix. Our effective tax rate was 15.7%, in line with the 15% to 20% range we communicated previously. 
The year-over-year increase in corporate was due in part to the inclusion of Morton Salt's results in the first quarter of last year. Our current quarter results also included higher performance share compensation and increased participation in our employee stock purchase program. We view this as a positive as it aligns the interest of our employees with those of our shareholders. For modeling purposes, you should expect corporate to run in the range of $150 million to $250 million per quarter.
Moving to Slide 11. Overall volume growth versus the same quarter last year was 16% on a pro forma basis, excluding divestitures. With our combined Performance segments, delivering an impressive 19% increase. We also achieved price gains in nearly all segments in double-digit increases across all geographies. Prices was up an impressive 16% in North America and 24% in Europe. On a sequential basis, price is up in all geographic regions with the exception of Europe. Again, North America showed strength with gains at 8%. Volume was up 4% versus the fourth quarter of last year but particular strength in both North America and Europe.
Now let's take a look at how the company performed on a segment level starting on Slide 14. In Electronic and Specialty Materials, volume was up 31% compared to the first quarter of 2009. In fact, volume in our Electronic Materials business was up 55% year-over-year. This reflect increased demand in memory, logic and display technologies. Our semiconductor technologies are capturing share as this sector continues to recover. We also are seeing substantial growth in the demand for water applications as these fundamental markets recover, contributing to substantial improvement in EBITDA margins across Specialty Materials. 
In Coatings and Infrastructure, volume increased 16%, excluding divestitures, while price was up 5%. Emerging regions are driving increased demand, while commercial construction continued to represent a challenge in North America and Europe. We are, however, seeing global improvements in residential construction end markets. I think it's important to highlight that excluding divestitures, EBITDA in this segment actually improved year-over-year. We also increased R&D spending as we move the investment in our POWERHOUSE Solar Shingle program into the business this quarter, as we're getting quarter closer to commercialization. Taking both of these points into consideration, EBITDA actually improved 8%. In our Acrylic-based Architectural Coatings business generated a solid EBITDA margin of around 15%. Coatings and Infrastructure should see further margin improvement as the businesses continue to work aggressively to recapture price related to more than 25% sequential increase in propylene, combined with seasonal volume increases.
Moving to Health and Ag Sciences. Both price and volume were down slightly on a year-over-year basis due to continued oversupply of glyphosate. This segment still holds significant growth potential looking forward. Our new Ag Chem molecules continue to gain traction. Our Seeds, Traits and Oil platform continue to grow and the introduction of SmartStax corn hybrids is continuing to meet our expectations.
In Performance Systems, volumes increased 27% with increases in all geographies and business units, primarily driven by: Dow Automotive, which benefited from increases in automotive demand in North America and Asia; and robust elastomer demand in all geographies, due to continued strength in food packaging, a sector that has been extremely resilient during the recent economic downturn.
Finally on this slide, you can see the primary drivers for Performance Products, which posted volume gains of 27%, excluding divestitures and price gains of 14%. Volume was up in all geographies and business units driven by consumer-led demand growth in Polyurethanes and growth in appliance-end markets driven by government incentives and energy-efficient standards.
Slide 16 details the performance of our Basic Plastics segment. Sales increased 49% year-over-year and EBITDA was $718 million for the quarter. Volume and price increases in Polyethylene were the largest contributor. Here, operating rates were high in the quarter enabling the business to focus on price. 
And finally in Basic Chemicals, volume increased 16% and price increased 6%. The major drivers in performance for this segment were an increase in demand for caustic soda in North America, due to the strength in the alumina industry, and a fourth consecutive quarter of price increases in Vinyl Chloride Monomer, which more than offset volume declines.
Now turning to Slide 17. Another high point in the quarter was equity earnings. We have rebounded strongly over the past five quarters, and now exceed pre-recession levels. In the first quarter, we delivered a record $304 million in equity earnings, up more than $200 million year-over-year. 
Turning to Slide 18. Our focus on financial discipline continued in the quarter with tight control on working capital. Our CapEx spending was under $300 million in the quarter. However, I like to point out that the first quarter is typically a low quarter for us in terms of capital spending, and we do anticipate an increase next quarter due to scheduled turnarounds.
It is important to note that due to the adoption of new accounting standards in the first quarter, ASU 2009-17 previously referred to as FAS 167, our investment in our Thailand joint venture will be recognized as CapEx going forward, bringing our total spending closer to $2 billion for the year. However, I also like to point out that this change will not increase our actual cash outflows.
Cash flow from operations was slightly higher in the quarter versus a year ago. And remember, our receivables are higher as a result of our higher sales and we experienced a normal inventory builds in our seasonal businesses. We remain on track to generate $1.5 billion in free cash flow in 2010.
Our net debt to capital rose slightly in the quarter, due to the adoption of the new accounting standards I just previously mentioned, changing the accounting treatment for some of our liabilities. Despite this change, we remain committed to achieving our 2010 goal of 45% net debt to total cap by year end. With the increase of our profitability this quarter, our net-debt-to-EBITDA multiple improved by 0.5 to 3.2. And we are on a run rate of 2.8 exiting the quarter.
I'd also like to highlight, we continue to make meaningful progress on our cost synergy and restructuring goals achieving $275 million in total cost reduction for the quarter, achieving an annualized run rate of $1.8 billion. 
That wraps up my review of the details for the quarter. And I'll pass it back to Andrew.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. I'd now like to spend a few minutes discussing the growth potential of a new Dow. This is clearly the central element of our strategy and our story. We have the right portfolio, the right geographic footprint and the right innovation pipe
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. I'd now like to spend a few minutes discussing the growth potential of a new Dow. This is clearly the central element of our strategy and our story. We have the right portfolio, the right geographic footprint and the right innovation pipeline. And I want to emphasize, we have all of this today. 
So I'd like to share with you a new and actually a more granular looked at our innovation pipeline, and update you on the growth synergies we're realizing in our new portfolio. So please turn to Slide 19, where you'll see we currently have more than 500 projects in our innovation playbook. And these are strategically aligned with our four megatrends. 
This impressive playbook is supported by our significant investment in research and development, which this year will be another $1.6 billion. This investment is aimed squarely at the intersection of society's greatest needs and business opportunities. 
Our innovation pipeline represents $30 billion on a non-risk-adjusted NPV. Consistent with our strategy and as you would expect, you see the pipeline is most robust in our Performance segments.
On Slide 20, when you look at it from a stage gate perspective, you can see that we have no shortage of new projects at the early stage of our pipeline. But equally exciting is how many are at an advanced stage and near commercialization. We have a very rigorous process to ensure our programs deliver commercial success. On a risk-adjusted basis, these programs represent $12.5 billion of net present value. And as you can see, the value is clearly tilted to implementation.
On Slide 21, I give you a few examples of some of the innovation projects that are yielding results today. Firstly, we have successfully commercialized next generation STYROFOAM Brand Insulation in North America, which provides customers the same great performance with a much improved and better-than-alternative products environmental profile. Our proprietary technology was the result of a multi-year effort led by one of our researchers, who by the way was recognized as a co-recipient for his contributions with a 2007 Nobel Prize. The technology gives us a significant competitive advantage in the market place, which is reflected in our first quarter results. 
In our Electronics business, we opened up a new display materials manufacturing facility late last year in Korea. This plant was fully operational in the first quarter, which was critical to meet increasing demand for display chemicals and OLED materials, two very fast-growing areas of the industry. This new capacity came on at a good time as Asian panel manufacturers are now running at full capacity.
And in our Polyurethanes business, we launched a new technology that delivers productivity gains for our key appliance customers, including energy savings and productivity efficiency, while lowering their raw material consumption. We are gaining market share as a result. In fact, Haier, one of the world's largest appliance manufacturers recently recognized Dow with their Best Strategic Supplier award, thanks in part to this technology. 
When you turn to Slide 22 and look at acquisition-related growth synergies, we're capturing tangible value from a range of new market opportunities. Let me just give you a few examples. 
We've landed a new long-term multi-year amines agreement with a strategic customer. We gained new sales for acrylic monomers with an industry-leading adhesives producer. We developed new solutions in Latin America that enhanced oil and gas production. We generated new biocides sales for water treatment applications. We secured higher margin, higher value PO-derivatives businesses in the food sector through focused marketing. We invented new novel polyolefin dispersion-based technology that has been adopted by a leading, global consumer products company. There are many more examples. And most of these have enabled us to achieve the $530 million in revenue already on a run-rate basis, which already surpasses our full year 2010 goal.
These growth projects clearly illustrate how the acquisition of Rohm and Haas provided the perfect opportunity to renew our existing customer relationships, jumpstart innovation and build stronger partnerships. Our commercial activities have been re-energized, not just in Advanced Materials, but across the entire enterprise. And this mindset is proliferating. Proliferating through every part of our company, enabling us to grow faster and more profitably. Nowhere is this more evident than in Dow Advanced Materials division, where an entrepreneurial spirit is thriving. That's one of the primary reasons we chose Jerome Peribere to run this division. As the former head of Dow AgroSciences, he led an organization that today is one of Dow's most profitable growth-oriented businesses. This is a perfect time to ask him to talk about some of the key drivers of growth in his portfolio.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. In the Dow Advanced Materials, we drive an empowered culture, where every employee has an owner mindset, and is accountable for delivering results while building a new and valuable technology pipeline and channel to market that sustain
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. In the Dow Advanced Materials, we drive an empowered culture, where every employee has an owner mindset, and is accountable for delivering results while building a new and valuable technology pipeline and channel to market that sustain our future growth. 
My comments today will only scratch the surface of our progress, but we're hosting an Investor Event next month, where we will have an even richer discussion of Dow Advanced Materials and our winning formula for growth. And I would invite you to turn on to Slide 23, where you will see that our businesses serve a broad and diverse range of high growth end markets, and their recognized leaders in their respective industries. These businesses employ a model that focuses on technology-intensive innovations and high-touch customer service. I'm proud to say that we have made tremendous progress in creating a formidable portfolio of high-growth and high-margin businesses.
As you know, we gained from Rohm and Haas an impressive electronics business, an industry-leading acrylics platform, a strong customer intimacy model and a large and growing presence in Asia. To this, we added Dow's strong industrial coatings position and we blended our industry-leading Water businesses, our Building and Construction franchises and our vast geographic reach and hitting power.  Last year, our division had sales in the excess of $9 billion, representing about 20% of Dow total sales and contributing almost a third of total Dow's EBITDA. I'd like to touch upon some of these key business drivers for growth and profitability, and invite you to turn to Slide 24.
Dow Electronics Materials is a leading producer of technologies that enable the production of memory chips, displays and other critical components that power today's electronic devices. The business is strongly tied to demand for consumer electronic devices, which has rebounded significantly this year. In fact, this business is already operating at peak profitability despite volumes that are 20% below normalized levels. Our technology position and speed to market led to several significant wins in the quarter, with leading global memory and logic manufacturer's as well as display producers.
Turning now onto our Building and Construction business, which like the broader Dow, has substantially reduced its cost base while continuing to invest in innovation. Since 2006, this business has increased average revenue per single-family housing start in the U.S. by some 80%, benefiting from increasing regulations and product innovation. And in high-growth regions like China, we recently launched our External Insulation Finishing System, which enhances energy performance and lowers overall installation costs.
Dow Coatings Materials is the world's largest supplier of coating raw materials to the global paint and coating industry. This business holds the broadest range of coating chemistries in the world, and the largest R&D commitment in the industry. You can see this already in our ultra low VOC formulations. Today's technologies cannot offer ultra low VOC and deliver the performance properties that customers expect. Our tremendous expertise in Emulsion Polymers and high throughput R&D capabilities has led to rapid ultra low VOC innovations that meet demanding performance requirements, and are now in the hands of many customers. We expect to revolutionize the coating industry in the next five years, thanks to major additions to our technology toolkits.
On Slide 25, our Coating business isn't the only area where we see the benefits of addressing environmental trends. Dow Adhesives and Functional Polymers is meeting demands for more lightweight and biodegradable packaging materials. This business increased penetration of water-based lamination adhesives, and is very well-positioned to meet the industry's demand to move from solvent-based materials. And we are further strengthening our portfolio in the global packaging arena by leveraging expertise from other areas in Dow that also touched this very large and growing sector. Expect to hear more about this as the year progresses.
And finally, our large Specialty Materials portfolio serves markets ranging from food and nutrition to household care, moving to biocides. You may know that this business best for the industry-leading water portfolio. This is an area where we've created the world's largest reverse osmosis membrane and Ion Exchange business. The benefits of our technology have already been rewarded in the marketplace and consider this, about half of the world's largest membrane desalinization plants that have started up in the last two years are using Dow technology.
On Slide 26, we have a broad portfolio of innovations valued at more than $7 billion NPV. We will provide a very detailed review of our Advanced Materials portfolio at our Sector Day on May 15, in Philadelphia. And I hope that you'll be able to join us and take advantage of this opportunity to see examples of our growth projects and hear directly from our business and technology leaders. Dow Advanced Materials is an incredibly exciting place to be right now, and I hope you'll watch us closely in the months and quarter to come.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Jerome. I'd like to you to turn to Slide 27 because I'd really would love to mention Dow Corning, which is another key growth driver for our Electronics and Specialty Materials Operating segment. You know, Dow Corning has been growing
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Jerome. I'd like to you to turn to Slide 27 because I'd really would love to mention Dow Corning, which is another key growth driver for our Electronics and Specialty Materials Operating segment. 
You know, Dow Corning has been growing its top line in a robust pace, 10% per year for the last 10 years. Now you can understand why we are excited about the future of this joint venture when you consider Dow Corning's leading global silicons position and the tremendous growth of its polysilicon joint venture, Hemlock Semiconductor. Due in large part to strong fundamentals and a solid industry, Hemlock's capacity will have expanded by more than 10x by 2015. Dow Corning will also be a part of the Advanced Materials' Sector Day in Philadelphia, so that's one more reason for you to attend. 
Please turn to Slide 28, where I'm going to now turn to our outlook. The global economy is showing signs of a meaningful recovery. Clearly, the most significant piece of new information is the robust improvement we've seen in North America and Europe. Two geographic areas that until now have lagged the recovery of the world economy. Our 27% sales growth in North America and 35% growth in Europe are compelling proof points that economic recovery is now underway in these areas. These numbers are even more impressive when you consider that volume gains comprised of full 11% of the growth in each region, showing that demand is indeed returning. Broad-based strength in many sectors of North America, such as Electronics to Automotive to Furniture shows a sustainable upturn is emerging. Even housing starts have shown more positive signs in recent weeks, as new home sales surged 27% in March, the highest gains in more than 40 years. Also, new orders for durable U.S. manufactured goods excluding transportation, posted the largest gains in more than two years last month. Strength in all of these sectors illustrates that the consumer is finally returning.
The story for emerging geographies is strong growth continuing at a robust pace. Volume growth of 27% versus one year ago with China, Brazil, Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia and India are leading the way. In fact, volume growth, as we've already said, in Greater China, was an impressive 46%. This strong performance coupled with the recovering demand in North America and Europe is driving notable manufacturing momentum and bode particularly well for Dow. We recognize there are some continuing challenges, especially in the construction industry and unemployment and tight credit conditions continue to weigh on consumer sentiment. However, to date, these have been balanced by improving consumer and business spending. 
So our outlook is one of a strengthening global economic environment with increasing signs of sustained growth. We saw the results of this growth in the first quarter through both volume growth and margin expansion, driven by our new portfolio and the benefits of our significant cost reduction efforts. And as we turn to our priorities in the coming quarter, we will continue to remain focused on delivering our commitments. This means maintaining operational and financial discipline, further strengthening our balance sheet and investing for growth. Our actions to deliver a new portfolio with a lean cost structure and reinvigorated innovation engine, coupled with our strong presence in emerging geographies, lead Dow poised to deliver continued earnings momentum. 
This quarter was indeed a pivotal point, and giving the world a glimpse of our earnings power of the constant and consistent progress we are making in driving our strategic agenda forward. Quarter-after-quarter, we are displaying a new Dow, a Dow that delivers earnings growth for its shareholders. Stay tuned as we continue to demonstrate the power of this new company.
I will now turn the call back to Howard

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

Before we do though, I'd like to remind you that my comments on forward-looking statements and non-GAAP financial measures apply to both of our prepared remarks and anything that may come up during the Q&A. Karen, would you please explain the Q&A procedure.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andrew, with shale gas keeping natural gas prices low in the U.S., wouldn't K-Dow be more valuable now due to this advantage? And how are you communicating this advantage to potential buyers?
componenttext: Andrew, with shale gas keeping natural gas prices low in the U.S., wouldn't K-Dow be more valuable now due to this advantage? And how are you communicating this advantage to potential buyers?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly, as we referenced in the call, P.J., the performance of our Polyethylene businesses is indeed impressive and there's a couple of reasons for that, not the least of them being the one you raised, which is U.S. natural gas. And of course, ethane has
componenttext: Clearly, as we referenced in the call, P.J., the performance of our Polyethylene businesses is indeed impressive and there's a couple of reasons for that, not the least of them being the one you raised, which is U.S. natural gas. And of course, ethane has decoupled from naphtha and oil and that arbitrage has now been open for a while. And if you go into the next several years and you take the shale gas production that will come online in this country, then that, in our view, is a sustainable advantage for some years. The consequence of that is that U.S. natural gas will start to stabilize, be less volatile, as will indeed natural gas liquids. This will still not be competitive versus the Middle East. The Middle East has the lowest cost of natural gas and ethane. But when you throw on top of that the notion that the Middle East is running out of natural gas liquid production and ethane in particular, it is mostly dry gas, with the exception of Iran, then the U.S. production base and the U.S. asset base that is in-market and has flexibility of cracker feedstocks, which ours does, ours is the most flexible in the industry, then it has an advantage in-market. And therefore, has made the business and the assets more valuable for the foreseeable future. That value is being demonstrated in the results, even though these are trough-like conditions. The business is earning 4x to 5x what it earned in the '01, '02 trough, which is a spectacular statement, not the least of the reasons being that we are relying less and less in exports, although of course, export windows open and close, based on this newfound arbitrage, could be more sustainable. How are we communicating it? Well, we're pacing ourselves. Because we have earned the right to do the right transaction at the right time, even though the strategy is exactly the way we want it to be, to be a more predictable earnings growth company. The up and down of the cyclicality of that business is something that hurts that. The fact that this business is earning this much money has made the business more valuable. And we are definitely taking our time in structuring the right deal. We've earned that right. How this unfolds over the next many quarters? We'll be really driven by maximizing the value that you alluded to in your question. And ultimately, the answer to your question is a resounding, yes. It has improved and increased the value of our franchise.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up on that, as ethylene benefits by the same token, propylene is getting hurt, and you buy a lot of propylene through the old Rohm and Haas business. So can you size for us the ethylene advantage versus propylene disadvantage?
componenttext: And just a follow up on that, as ethylene benefits by the same token, propylene is getting hurt, and you buy a lot of propylene through the old Rohm and Haas business. So can you size for us the ethylene advantage versus propylene disadvantage?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, propylene as you well know, there's several ways to get there. Refinery-based propylene clearly, being one of the key ones in the United States, which usually makes the U.S. propylene long. What of course has happened over these many years, is as yo
componenttext: Well, propylene as you well know, there's several ways to get there. Refinery-based propylene clearly, being one of the key ones in the United States, which usually makes the U.S. propylene long. What of course has happened over these many years, is as you go to a line of feedstock the propylene coming out of crackers reduces. And therefore, potentially, especially with declining refinery margins, propylene could go short, which is and in fact has started to do. Now as we look at the outlook for propylene, we see actually the supply-demand balance is improving, particularly in the third quarter. And one of the biggest reasons for that is the world's largest propane dehydro unit in Texas will come online and produce on-purpose propylene. Propane dehydro is prevalent elsewhere around the world, notably in the Middle East. But for it to be prevalent here in the U.S., decouples propylene. And remember, we actually consume a lot of propylene, but we produce half of it. So we produce half of the propylene we consume. We do believe that propylene will see some near-term price drops. As a consequence of that, the propylene arbitrage to ethylene will be less. Clearly, also on the back end of this year, there could be a drop in ethylene because of excess supply coming on in the Middle East. So we do believe this first half in ethylene, polyethylene is strong, that natural gas arbitrage will be good. But having said that, its sustainability with excess supply coming on the back half, we'll see that start to drop, but we believe will benefit on the propylene side of that.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Don Carson with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Don Carson with UBS.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to shift over to the Ag side. You mentioned that SmartStax is meeting all its milestones, yet your partner seems to have missed some of their volume milestones. So two questions. One, what impact did that have on your earnings? Two, given that Mons
componenttext: I want to shift over to the Ag side. You mentioned that SmartStax is meeting all its milestones, yet your partner seems to have missed some of their volume milestones. So two questions. One, what impact did that have on your earnings? Two, given that Monsanto's going to price more aggressively on so-called price-per-penetration strategy, does that have any impact on Dow AgroSciences' income going forward?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, on Ag, I think the key message here is independent of what our partner has said. You've got to know and remember that we priced SmartStax independent of them. And we have two key objectives in our strategy that may be different to their original stra
componenttext: Yes, on Ag, I think the key message here is independent of what our partner has said. You've got to know and remember that we priced SmartStax independent of them. And we have two key objectives in our strategy that may be different to their original strategy. Firstly, a rapid transition of our portfolio, the SmartStax is very key to Dow. And two, to grow our market shares. So we've always priced SmartStax over TripleStax [ph](1:00:20) to reflect the incremental value the technology brings. But the same time, penetration pricing has been our mantra. So we're doing everything. We're meeting our goals, where everything we said we'd do, we have done. There's no question that even with the revised numbers from our partner, 3 million makers is still one of the largest biotech launches in history. We're selling everything we have available to sell. There are no surprises in our field trials. And we're achieving the results that we said we would achieve. In fact, we're very confident. We were actually -- are launching SmartStax to nearly 40 hybrids this season, and expect to have SmartStax in more than 70% of our corn portfolio in the next two to three years. So we're on target, no effect from the partner's announcements to us. We're on strategy and we see absolutely no negative affect to our forecasts.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Andrew, just to clarify then, your royalty fee from Monsanto doesn't go down even if their price to the grower is going down?
componenttext: So Andrew, just to clarify then, your royalty fee from Monsanto doesn't go down even if their price to the grower is going down?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have stayed away. I think you know, Don, from answering that specific question, I know people want to know that. But we stay true to our organic growth strategy, which is actually a lot of where we're deriving our NPV value.
componenttext: Well, we have stayed away. I think you know, Don, from answering that specific question, I know people want to know that. But we stay true to our organic growth strategy, which is actually a lot of where we're deriving our NPV value.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: For our next question, we'll go to Sergey Vasnetsov with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: For our next question, we'll go to Sergey Vasnetsov with Barclays Capital.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: All segments have shown a significant improvement, Andrew, but Basic Plastics segments shined with 20.5% EBITDA margin at a time of supposed trough. And so I'm mindful that since for our business is [ph](1:01:57) coming up and down. But more broadly acros
componenttext: All segments have shown a significant improvement, Andrew, but Basic Plastics segments shined with 20.5% EBITDA margin at a time of supposed trough. And so I'm mindful that since for our business is [ph](1:01:57) coming up and down. But more broadly across other commodity chemical companies and products and regions, it seems to me that the profitability has been achieved with a high level of high profits with a low operating rates compared to what we've seen the past. So have you seen the same and does that suggest that maybe the overall market discipline is better this trough compared to what we've seen in previous times?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It could be market discipline. I probably would give you that. But I really do think the bigger reason is actions we and others have taken in Europe and U.S. to right-size the footprint. Especially here in the U.S. and Canada to not really have the export
componenttext: It could be market discipline. I probably would give you that. But I really do think the bigger reason is actions we and others have taken in Europe and U.S. to right-size the footprint. Especially here in the U.S. and Canada to not really have the export capacity in key downstream businesses. Remember, we shuttered EDC, EB/Styrene, EO/EG. And really, reconfigured the footprint for our Basic Plastics PE, in particular, here to a U.S. demand. And we are definitely the most competitive in the United States, Canada, as a result, due to our flexi crackers. So to your generic point, we do believe that it's elevated the performance of the business to a new level, when you throw on top of it the low-cost feedstocks we have available to us in places like Kuwait and Argentina. So the Dow strategy of asset-light low-cost feedstock place elsewhere to do petroceuticals, to use your favorite term, famous term actually, plus of course, the in-market competitiveness thrown on top of that, the first question from P.J. on natural gas in the U.S. and the arbitrage point has given the business a new level of performance in trough-like conditions. There is still upside based on basically price volume maximization. We're still way below peak margin levels, so there's still upside.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It seems like Dow, again, making more money today at 83% capitalization if I were to compare these data points with the past. Do you think that's what Dow you were able to lower your break even points or cost of doing business so that you can make more mo
componenttext: It seems like Dow, again, making more money today at 83% capitalization if I were to compare these data points with the past. Do you think that's what Dow you were able to lower your break even points or cost of doing business so that you can make more money at the same operating rates compared to the past?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, to make sure I get lots of questions in today, the answer is going to be just a yes.  We have lowered our break even point with all of the $2 billion of cost reductions in the combined company plus restructuring. The answer is yes.
componenttext: Yes, to make sure I get lots of questions in today, the answer is going to be just a yes.  We have lowered our break even point with all of the $2 billion of cost reductions in the combined company plus restructuring. The answer is yes.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Robert Koort with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Robert Koort with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andrew, it seems to me you generated about $1 billion of incremental EBITDA year-over-year, and the bulk of it was from commodity end markets, although I guess now we're seeing a little bit better pick up on the specialty side. Do you expect a bit of a se
componenttext: Andrew, it seems to me you generated about $1 billion of incremental EBITDA year-over-year, and the bulk of it was from commodity end markets, although I guess now we're seeing a little bit better pick up on the specialty side. Do you expect a bit of a seesaw as we go into the second half where the commodities may see a fade versus some pretty good numbers last year? Or do you think those can sustain while the downstream businesses continue to expand in terms of profit?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there's no question the mix, if you look at the leverage we have to economic recovery right now and the statements we made, in particular, around global recovery in North America and Europe in particular, the propylene envelope and all of its
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there's no question the mix, if you look at the leverage we have to economic recovery right now and the statements we made, in particular, around global recovery in North America and Europe in particular, the propylene envelope and all of its downstream-s, and you pick your favorite ones, polyurethanes, acrylics, emulsions, also of course epoxies. There is definitely margin inflation in the first quarter that we will start to recover as the year goes by in, let's call it, the semi-commodity part of the mix. If you really look at the downstream part of the company now, Electronic Materials, Specialty Materials, if you look at Ag, it's independent of the questions. So really, we have a third of the portfolio that's independent of the hydrocarbon story. We have another third that should see better improvement in the Specialty side as the year unfolds. And then the third, that's Basic Plastics, in particular, and Basic Chemicals, particularly Polyethylene, should see some margin compression in the back half of the year as excess supply comes on. So we'll tilt the performance, as you say, moving parts to the Performance side as the year progresses, which is by the way on strategy.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are we right to read that there was $200 million to $300 million of employee comp that hit that other, the corporate line that might not be so big in the remaining quarters? Is that the way to think about it?
componenttext: Are we right to read that there was $200 million to $300 million of employee comp that hit that other, the corporate line that might not be so big in the remaining quarters? Is that the way to think about it?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not disclosing the exact amount, but that's fairly close. But it was largely driven by the employee stock purchase plan. In the corporate, right, Corporate segment went up, I think, about $400 million. But as I pointed out in my comments, a yea
componenttext: Yes. We're not disclosing the exact amount, but that's fairly close. But it was largely driven by the employee stock purchase plan. In the corporate, right, Corporate segment went up, I think, about $400 million. But as I pointed out in my comments, a year ago, we had results of more than in there, so that's part of it. And then we had a very strong participation on employee stock purchase plan, which we think is great news. It also reflects the fact that the value of our stock has also gone up. So yes, you're in the ballpark. But I would say, I'd like to point to you, going forward, think about that segment, if you will, being in the $150 million to $250 million range.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And John McNulty with Credit Suisse has our next question.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question with regard to your R&D pipeline. If I remember correctly, back in November, Bill Banholzer had highlighted that he thought over the next three years or so, you'd have about $2 billion of revenue coming from your R&D pipeline. How do
componenttext: Just a quick question with regard to your R&D pipeline. If I remember correctly, back in November, Bill Banholzer had highlighted that he thought over the next three years or so, you'd have about $2 billion of revenue coming from your R&D pipeline. How does that compare with your implementation part of the R&D pipeline you just highlighted earlier at $5.6 billion? Is that roughly about the same type of timeline that we should be thinking about? And has that number has gotten bigger? How should we compare the two?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the $2 billion revenue number that Bill referred to comes from both growth synergies and the organic R&D pipeline. And the way you should think about that slide we had in the deck is that the NPV risk-adjusted is derived from revenue margin projectio
componenttext: Yes, the $2 billion revenue number that Bill referred to comes from both growth synergies and the organic R&D pipeline. And the way you should think about that slide we had in the deck is that the NPV risk-adjusted is derived from revenue margin projections with firm stage gates between now, 2012 and beyond. But clearly, those projects that are at or near commercialization tilt the number very much to the here and now of $2 billion revenue in 2012. So at the end of the day, John, that's the same number.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the $5.6 billion still corresponds to the $2 billion that will actually materialize?
componenttext: So the $5.6 billion still corresponds to the $2 billion that will actually materialize?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've obviously seen quite a lot of raw material inflation in the Performance divisions during the quarter. Can you quantify the effect of margins that had in the Performance Products division?
componenttext: You've obviously seen quite a lot of raw material inflation in the Performance divisions during the quarter. Can you quantify the effect of margins that had in the Performance Products division?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, this is Bill Weideman. Yes, actually, if you were to look at our Performance businesses, we had about $200 million of marketing compression in the second quarter. And as you know, our results show better than that, that was because of the conti
componenttext: Yes, Paul, this is Bill Weideman. Yes, actually, if you were to look at our Performance businesses, we had about $200 million of marketing compression in the second quarter. And as you know, our results show better than that, that was because of the continued realization of synergies. But roughly, it was about $200 million of margin compression. As we anticipated, as we've mentioned before, that we have about a 60-, 90-day lag in increase in prices there. But as you know, going forward, if propylene goes down, that trend should change, and we should see margin expansions.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're fairly optimistic about the outlook in Europe. And I've just come back from Europe, actually, and the outlook there, to me, looked quite worrisome. Perhaps, you could just talk in which end markets you're seeing significant growth in
componenttext: It sounds like you're fairly optimistic about the outlook in Europe. And I've just come back from Europe, actually, and the outlook there, to me, looked quite worrisome. Perhaps, you could just talk in which end markets you're seeing significant growth in, please.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Europe, I would characterize as lagging behind the U.S., so I don't want to overplay the statement. I think, depending on where you were in Europe, we're seeing, in particular, Germany, with its export orientation being quite strong as the euro keeps
componenttext: Yes, Europe, I would characterize as lagging behind the U.S., so I don't want to overplay the statement. I think, depending on where you were in Europe, we're seeing, in particular, Germany, with its export orientation being quite strong as the euro keeps dropping because of the issues around sovereign debt. Germany is doing quite well and well for us. And there's a plethora of different ways we see it. We see it, for example, in our Insulation business, energy efficiency measures that have come through government's stimuli, not just in Germany, but across other countries in Europe like France in particular, Northern Europe, and also over into Eastern Europe. And in fact, we are seeing Eastern Europe coming back stronger. That's a quicker rebound than Western Europe. But that helps Western Europe, in particular. It helps Germany in particular. So there's no one particular market other than, I would say to you, generically, it's in the areas of infrastructure and transportation and exports.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next we have David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next we have David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andrew, given the strength of your innovation pipeline, how much fast should the Performance businesses grow as a multiple of GDP over the next, perhaps, three to five years?
componenttext: Andrew, given the strength of your innovation pipeline, how much fast should the Performance businesses grow as a multiple of GDP over the next, perhaps, three to five years?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you know, there's so many Performance businesses. They all have their own demand drive. Electronic Materials, for example, should be at 2x GDP number. So that's -- I need to say it, I mean, because Jerome mentioned that. But when you come to May 1
componenttext: Yes, as you know, there's so many Performance businesses. They all have their own demand drive. Electronic Materials, for example, should be at 2x GDP number. So that's -- I need to say it, I mean, because Jerome mentioned that. But when you come to May 18 Sector Day, you're going to see the power of the synergies in Electronic Materials. We've lowered the cost point because of the synergies on the cost side. But the GDP growth out in Asia, in particular, and all the stuff that we're doing, is seeing double digit, twice-type GDP growth rate, actually, about 1.5x. And Performance Systems, probably a little lower than that, 1.3x, 1.4x GDP. And Performance Products, probably around 1x GDP.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just on those subject, looking at Ras Tanura and your China coal-to-chemicals project, how important are those two projects for your growth over a longer term basis?
componenttext: And just on those subject, looking at Ras Tanura and your China coal-to-chemicals project, how important are those two projects for your growth over a longer term basis?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Critical. I would say, we have one project ahead of those two, which is the Thai project. That should come on in the next year or year and half. That will be great for our expansion out in the Far East and the growth markets out there. There's a range of
componenttext: Critical. I would say, we have one project ahead of those two, which is the Thai project. That should come on in the next year or year and half. That will be great for our expansion out in the Far East and the growth markets out there. There's a range of different products we're building there. And then the next one will be Ras Tanura, and then the following one will be China coal. And these are all asset-light projects, all building blocks projects, that will help feed Jerome's business, help feed Performance Systems, and make sure that we have the downstream value add that the strategy speaks to.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Next we'll go to Frank Mitsch with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just looking at some math here and I was just trying to rectify or clarify, the 83% operating rate that you did back in the second quarter of '08 versus the 83% today. And obviously, on an EPS basis, it was better back then. The company looked a lit
componenttext: I was just looking at some math here and I was just trying to rectify or clarify, the 83% operating rate that you did back in the second quarter of '08 versus the 83% today. And obviously, on an EPS basis, it was better back then. The company looked a little bit better. But I was looking through some numbers on a pro forma basis, I actually think that the company performed a bit better back in the second quarter of '08 with Rohm and Haas. Are the numbers wrong here? What might be the differences here that we should expect, as the operating rates move up, that we will get better performance than what was generated back a couple of years ago?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, Frank, there's lots of moving parts, right? So the number of assets that have been taken down, especially on the commodity side, the hydrocarbon and energy compression that's occurred in this quarter versus the quarter back then, propylene i
componenttext: Well, I mean, Frank, there's lots of moving parts, right? So the number of assets that have been taken down, especially on the commodity side, the hydrocarbon and energy compression that's occurred in this quarter versus the quarter back then, propylene in particular, the question that was asked earlier on propylene cost base, the propylene cost base is going up. There's a lot of moving parts. So I think the way we look at 2008, that quarter was an 83% operating rate. We've lowered the cost point of the company on structural cost for the combined company by the two big restructurings that were taken, one by Rohm and Haas, one by Dow. When you put those two together, that's about a $750 million take out of cost from structural costs. And then the $1.3 billion of synergies, that $2 billion will be out of the combined cost base that you saw back in the first quarter of '08. That will then, in turn, mean the volume, once you get the volumes up there, that'll all drop to the bottom line. And one way of explaining it is we use '07. If you take $6.5 billion of EBITDA in '07 from Dow, $2.5 billion of EBITDA from Rohm and Haas, that's $9 billion. Add the $2 billion of EBITDA from cost savings, that's $11 billion. And then if you add and subtract, add the equity earnings that we've had with Dow Corning expansions, Hemlock expansions, [indiscernible], that gives us up to around $11.5 billion, substract the sold businesses, that's $10.7 billion of EBITDA or $4.50 a share. That $10.7 billion of EBITDA, when will that be obtained? If you make the assumption that '12 will look like '07, then we're on the run rate to that number, based on the current asset footprint, not counting any of the growth pipeline.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's been a lot of press reports. The partners have not made a statement. Clearly, one of the things that both partners have examined long and hard is the capital burden of such a huge project at the get-go, even though it's an asset-light structure fo
componenttext: There's been a lot of press reports. The partners have not made a statement. Clearly, one of the things that both partners have examined long and hard is the capital burden of such a huge project at the get-go, even though it's an asset-light structure for us and for them. We have made no decision yet on any move, although Jubail has been assessed as an interesting alternative, that's being made available to the partners. We have basically within a few months of making final decisions on the feed, which is obviously the big commitment to go to the next step or the long-term equipment, and in fact, start detail design, and in fact, start side prep [ph]. So we'll have a lot to say, give us a few months.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Has the more favorable ethane dynamics on the U.S. Gulf Coast changed your higher level paradigm in terms of capital investment toward the Middle East?
componenttext: Has the more favorable ethane dynamics on the U.S. Gulf Coast changed your higher level paradigm in terms of capital investment toward the Middle East?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the things we're working very hard on that premise of your question is, as you know, we are a leader in talking about energy policy in this country. And we are trying very hard now with this revised Energy and Climate Change Bill that's coming out
componenttext: One of the things we're working very hard on that premise of your question is, as you know, we are a leader in talking about energy policy in this country. And we are trying very hard now with this revised Energy and Climate Change Bill that's coming out of the Senate, this KGL Bill, to ensure that we can lock in sustainable energy policies around natural gas in this country for many years to come. There's a couple of things that we've been saying about it. We're not yet certain we can lock it in, that's why we're not as bullish as your statements suggest. We want to be. We want to re-create an investment dynamic here in the U.S. around our asset base, based on long-term predictability on natural gas.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gauging downstream inventories from Dow has always sort of hard, but I looked at Praxair reported this morning and they do a manufacturing index of end markets. And they had manufacturing only up 1% globally versus last year's first quarter, in spite of t
componenttext: Gauging downstream inventories from Dow has always sort of hard, but I looked at Praxair reported this morning and they do a manufacturing index of end markets. And they had manufacturing only up 1% globally versus last year's first quarter, in spite of the easy comparisons, and that excluded chemicals. So your growth is much, much higher than what they were reporting as a manufacturing index growth. Do you think there's some pre-buying or buildup going on in advanced of all the price increases that have been going on?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely not. I don't know. I haven't looked at their numbers. We think it's about a 7% industrial production year-over-year comparator, which makes our volumes even more impressive. When you look at by sector, you look at thing like automotive. It's up
componenttext: Absolutely not. I don't know. I haven't looked at their numbers. We think it's about a 7% industrial production year-over-year comparator, which makes our volumes even more impressive. When you look at by sector, you look at thing like automotive. It's up incredibly high year-on-year. There's no question in our mind that this is beyond a restocking. This is now consumer-led demand recovery.

componenttext: And then lastly, it sounds like you have a different point of view toward your U.S. Petrochemical businesses because of sustainable advantages due to feedstocks. Is that right? Do you no longer want to sell that business?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We have a very clearly set of strategy. The strategy is to move Dow's portfolio to downstream value-add businesses, businesses like Jerome's, businesses like the Ag business. We have preferential investors. Our R&D budget, CapEx budget is all going th
componenttext: No. We have a very clearly set of strategy. The strategy is to move Dow's portfolio to downstream value-add businesses, businesses like Jerome's, businesses like the Ag business. We have preferential investors. Our R&D budget, CapEx budget is all going that way. But we need building blocks for those businesses. We will do them in an equity-light, asset-like structure. And over these next many quarters, we hope that we can get a higher value for our joint venture with our Basic Plastics unit, but we haven't changed strategy.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I hear that Polyethylene exports have dropped off, maybe inventories have overbuilt based on higher prices here. I wonder if you could bring us up to date on that. And separately, with your $2 billion goal on divestitures, is that a way to say, we
componenttext: Andrew, I hear that Polyethylene exports have dropped off, maybe inventories have overbuilt based on higher prices here. I wonder if you could bring us up to date on that. And separately, with your $2 billion goal on divestitures, is that a way to say, well, we don't expect a K-Dow type of deal to be done this year?

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the second question first, because it was a follow on from a previous question from Jeff. We don't know when a deal will be done. We don't count, as you quite rightly put in, the $2 billion number. We don't count a replacement deal to the K-
componenttext: Let me answer the second question first, because it was a follow on from a previous question from Jeff. We don't know when a deal will be done. We don't count, as you quite rightly put in, the $2 billion number. We don't count a replacement deal to the K-Dow deal in our numbers. That's correct. However, the timing of any such deal for us will be based on maximum valuation. I mean, I think what you should be hearing on this whole strategy, we're very pleased with the PE business. It's number one in the world. It's actually, technologically advanced. There's a right partner out there with feedstocks that, that business should be joint ventured with, but we're not counting on it this year. And that's the only way to interpret it, Bill. In terms of export windows from the U.S. on Polyethylene, I believe we moved a significant amount outside to China and Asia in the first quarter, about 20%. We looked very closely at prebuying the previous question. We don't see any signs of inventory builds based on perspective price drop.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Thanks very much, Bill. That ends the Q&A portion. Before we end the call, though, I'd like to ask Andrew to just make a few closing comments.

headline: The Dow Chemical Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just -- well, firstly, thank you all for listening to the call and Q&A. If you really look at the summary of the way we feel about things, we think this revenue run rate, we had a substantial revenue beat in the quarter, reflects those beginni
componenttext:
I'd like to just -- well, firstly, thank you all for listening to the call and Q&A. If you really look at the summary of the way we feel about things, we think this revenue run rate, we had a substantial revenue beat in the quarter, reflects those beginning signs of a new Dow, and in fact, an economic recovery with volume growth to the upside, not only, of course, in the emerging world, but now the U.S., and to a certain extent, parts of Europe, has demand pool going on, not restocking. We believe Rohm and Haas was a great acquisition for us. And we're demonstrating it earlier than anyone expected, on not only the bottom line, but also the top line, which feeds my revenue point. 
And the two things that were asked on the call in the Q&A, our cost reductions give us great leverage to economic upside and economic recovery. And then growth, will in fact drive the upside, and our innovations and the agenda around R&D. And I really urge you to come to May 18 Sector Day with Jerome, because he's going to show growth in all of its colors. Thank you for listening to us.
